title: Backup goalie, penalty kill lifting Flyers
text:
Latest hockey odds 
"The five guys on the ice are playing as one unit and they've been there for me," said Neuvirth, who had 31 saves against Florida and 30 against Chicago. 
After a shaky Mason, perhaps affected by a personal crisis, allowed four early goals in a 7-1 loss in Florida, Neuvirth blanked the same Panthers on Monday, 1-0, and then was flawless in the Flyers' workmanlike 3-0 win over the defending Stanley Cup champion Blackhawks on Wednesday. 
Giroux was asked what he liked best about Neuvirth's game. 
"That he doesn't let any goals in," he cracked. 
Giroux paused. 
"He works hard and doesn't quit on pucks," he added. "I know the fans here like to see second effort, and that's what he does." 
Flyers winger Jake Voracek isn't surprised at what he's seen from Neuvirth, whom he has known since they were growing up in the Czech Republic. 
"I've known him since I was 15 years old," Voracek said. "I played with him on the national team in Czech and he was always calm and relaxed in the net, and always had a talent. His work ethic in practices is impressive, so good for him. This was a huge win for him and us." 
Neuvirth became the second goalie in Flyers history to register shutouts in his first two starts with them - Jeff Hackett did it in 2003 - and the fifth in NHL history to accomplish the feat with any team. 
The much-maligned penalty kill, which was 27th in the NHL last season, has done its part after a poor start. 
The PK was successful on just 6 of 10 in the first two games, losses to Tampa Bay and Florida. Rookie coach Dave Hakstol downplayed the penalty killers' efficiency in those games, saying it came down to "a save, a bounce of the puck, an inch here or there that creates a turnover and the puck goes down the ice." 
In the last two games, both shutouts, the penalty kill was flawless. 
"We've been doing a pretty unbelievable job," said Pierre-Edouard Bellemare, who led the forwards with 4 minutes, 38 seconds of penalty-killing time against Chicago. "It felt like all the units were together [Wednesday]. It was four guys [working] together." 
Chicago had three third-period power plays, including a five-on-three for 23 seconds. 
"You try to go out there and don't give them the easy shot," Bellemare said. 
When Chicago did have a point-blank chance, Neuvirth stood tall. 
"You know you have the wall behind you," Bellemare said of the 6-foot, 209-pound goaltender. "Neuvy's making the saves we need to have him make." 
Breakaways. Backup goalie Jason LaBarbera was sent back to the Phantoms. . . . The Flyers are off until Tuesday, when they host Dallas.
